description.plain:
Marlon Roudette is a British-Carribean singer and songwriter, currently based in London. He is the son of Massive Attack member Cameron McVey and Vonnie Roudette and is the half brother of renowned singer and songwriter Mabel, who have frequently worked together in most of her recent music releases, spawning hits, such as Mabel’s “Finders Keepers” and “Fine Line” and, even more recently, Jax Jones’s “Ring Ring”.

Although born in London, Marlon Roudette spent most of his formative years in the Eastern Caribbean, where he fell in love with the reggae music that seemed to spill forth from every storefront.

He is the son of Massive Attack member Cameron McVey and Vonnie Roudette and is the half brother of renowned singer and songwriter Mabel, who have frequently worked together in most of her recent music releases, spawning hits, such as Mabel’s “Finders Keepers” and “Fine Line” and, even more recently, Jax Jones’s “Ring Ring”.

Although born in London, Marlon Roudette spent most of his formative years in the Eastern Caribbean, where he fell in love with the reggae music that seemed to spill forth from every storefront.

songs.full_title: When the Beat Drops Out by Marlon Roudette
songs.title: When the Beat Drops Out

description.plain:
“When the Beat Drops Out” is a song by British/Vincentian musician Marlon Roudette from his second studio album, Electric Soul (2014). The song was written by Marlon Roudette and Jamie Hartman. It was released in Germany on 18 July 2014 as the lead single from the album. It was released in the United Kingdom on 1 March 2015.

“When the Beat Drops Out” has charted at number one in Germany, number two in Austria and Switzerland, and number 15 in Australia. It also debuted and peaked at number 7 in the United Kingdom.

songs.embed_content: Read “When the Beat Drops Out” by Marlon Roudette on Genius

songs.title: New Age

description.plain: The début solo single by British singer and songwriter Marlon Roudette reached number one in Germany, as well as Austria and Switzerland. It also reached the top five in the Czech Republic, Poland and Slovakia and the top ten in the Netherlands and Wallonia. But it was a failure in his motherland, the UK, where it reached only number ninety.
